values:
It feels colder than nine degrees. It feels painfully, brutally cold. I don't really want to go outside for a long time. I want to stay in with my space heater and my fuzzy pants and my thick new rug (okay, it's my parents' castoff, but it's new to me, and it is soft underfoot and looks effing great in here, and do you think it should be centered, or at an angle like the old one, or sort of off-center in acknowledgement of the room's sort of off-centeredness?). 

Very few things are happening the way I'd expect them to happen. But I think that might be a blessing. A giant one, in fact.

In the first nineteen shiny-new days of the year, nearly everyone I care about (including me) has already had at least one uncontrollable sobbing fit or medical scare.

Additionally, I have torn a contact, doused a whole table in coffee, bruised my forehead, bruised my knees so badly I can hear them creaking, jumped the car three times, replaced the car battery, dropped or lost or left behind too many things to count, destroyed nearly every zipper on my suitcase, spilled soup on my good coat, knocked over a pot of orchids at a Jewel, done something to my left ankle that feels suspiciously like the old chronic sprain, and possibly wrecked one friendship, maybe two, maybe three.

This bodes well.

Several days ago I picked an ingredient from the cocoa package as my blues alter ego. This turns out to have been a prescient move, because my life has taken a turn for the blues lately. Ladies and Gentlemen, I give you Sweet Dairy Whey! ...No, who am I kidding? I can't come up with this song right now, largely because I'm listening to other music and enjoying it too much to turn it off to come up with lyrics I'll probably never perform. But here's proof that the Period of Broken Things isn't quite over yet: November 30: Door doesn't quite close, because of the August accident. I don't notice. Door light stays on. December 2: Battery dead. Self-charger (which you plug into an outlet for 36 hours, and then use as a jumper cable) purchased. Self-charger turns out to lack an AC cable and cannot be charged. December 3: N offers a jump. Both doors frozen shut. Key is in danger of snapping off. We cannot get under the hood. December 4: Self-charger exchanged, after long, cold walk. Door de-icer purchased. December 8: Successful jump-start from N. Engine runs for a good 30 minutes. December 9: Battery dead. Self-charger dead. N, with admirable generosity, offers another jump-start. Car starts. I climb in and prepare to drive for a long time. Rearview mirror comes off in my hand. I leave the engine running and go get some Superglue. I sit in the car, engine still running, and attempt several times to reattach the mirror. I glue myself to the windshield. I leave a little bit of skin there. I call my dad. Finally I give up and drive, mirrorless, to Sears, where they say the battery (still under warranty) is just fine. I'm a little worried about tomorrow. I have started knitting again. It calms me.

Just in case you thought the credit rating system was as scary as it got: http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20061201/ap_on_go_ca_st_pe/traveler_screening Your terror rating is on file for forty years. I don't think there's any kind of security installment plan that can dig you out of that one.

This is by far the latest I've ever finished, but the sheer fact that I finished? Awesome. N has an interesting hypothesis, involving the interrelation of creation and destruction, that I create so much my creative genius (as in the motivating spirit, not the ability) has to cause a lot of attendant destruction. As fuel. As balance. As something. In any case, the past couple of days offer plenty of support for this belief: - the car doors, one of which sprang open (surprise!) as I was driving to work yesterday, one of which wouldn't even let the key turn in the lock as I was trying to get home from work today - the 10,000 other drivers who tried their hardest to hit me on those commutes - last night's flat-out snide rejection slip for a short story (but I wound up working it, and the reply I wanted to send, into the NaNothing, so it's all good) - the bottle of cranberry juice, whose cap I should have checked before I shook it - the big dish of maple-tangerine glaze, which I poured all down the front of my good winter coat (also en route to work this morning) - the mural in the bathroom, which fell off the wall this morning (it was a rough morning all around) - the broken glass on the kitchen shelf, which I discovered right after N and I had a conversation about Periods of Broken Things I feel as though I'm forgetting something. Ah well. As N says, it's not massive crippling destruction. It sort of dances between annoying and funny. I choose funny. Maybe it's just what happens when you start taking risks. I don't know. In any case I've got this manuscript now. And all kinds of challenging, bruising circus skills to practice. And a few unexpected pieces of work that point unequivocally towards Italy. Accompanying all these Broken Things are a lot of really odd coincidences that whisper: One way or another, you are living rightly.

Finally, finally, the nuclear story is finished. Not a moment too soon, either, because a couple of days ago they--that should be capitalized, I suppose, the new all-powerful They of Homeland Security--arrested an unemployed U.S. citizen for little more than possession of "nuclear information" and a lot of cash. 

Nuclear information. Seriously? Thoughtcrime? Has it really come to that?

At least we don't have to worry about my ever having a lot of cash. Now I'm just an ordinary writer with overdue library books. Phew.

Oh, and I don't mean to brag, but guess who has a working kitchen sink again? Me, that's who! I know! No more bathtub dishwashing for me! This baby's movin' up! Nyeah nyeah nyeah! Jealous much?

There is really nothing like being on hold with the IRS and having the phone play "Waltz of the Flowers." Wow...this moment is beautiful in so many ways.

Perverse beauty throughout the world. I got on the highway at a different exit yesterday and the entire drive was new. I can't explain a damn thing, but I think I like it.
I just realized I have a biography of Oppenheimer overdue from the Chicago public library. This looks really bad, doesn't it?

The current plot situation is about to require me to Google "plutonium bomb." I just want to post that in case the search puts me on an watch lists. IT'S FICTION, GUYS. I DO NOT PERSONALLY WANT TO OBTAIN OR WEAPONIZE ANY PLUTONIUM. There, that ought to do the trick. It's really unfortunate that plot, as in "the main story of your crappy novel," and plot, as in "your secret plan to blow things up," are the same word.

This is what I really love about NaNoWriMo: Things Get Done. I make the phone calls. I pay the bills. I talk to the clients. I get the work. I do the work. I go to the gym. I do laundry. I vote.

Or--to take tonight, for example--I finish and hang the painting in the dining room, I clean up the painting mess, I venture out into a black thunderstorm to run errands, I finally deposit the checks, I finally get a fax/scanner for the office, I finally hang the other piece of art, I get the stuffing for the pretty pretty flower pillows, I make the pillows, I put them on the couch, I clean up the sewing mess. Because inside my head is a voice saying "Can't dawdle! Can't dawdle! THERE'S NO TIME!"

Now, it's true none of these tasks is novel-writing, in the strictest sense. But I have removed a whole lot of obstacles to novel-writing. And I love the way being several thousand words behind restores everything else to its proper proportion: the fact that even though I might be seriously sick and feverish, and have missed three days of work with a full-body rash, by hell I am typing.

Still behind. But considering I started the day at about 4,300, I'm in pretty damn good shape. My pace is really solid--when I actually write. I have become very adept this year at avoiding potentially ugly confrontations with my own thoughts, which means I've been writing less than I should. But I think my resistance is actually quite faint now, and I've let myself walk smack into a couple of confrontations already. So that's good. It's just a question of keeping it up for the remaining 80 percent of the book. Whatever the hell the book is. I decided a while ago that I really didn't need another unpublished novel hanging around, giving me guilt trips, so I would use this month to write out all the ideas I had in my grand creative ferment this spring and summer. So I've finished--or at least written up to insurmountable walls on--three stories so far. I suppose it's conceivable that all these stories will somehow wind up being connected (Dad suggests a framing device involving someone with multiple-personality disorder), so it turns out to be a loosely episodic piece of long fiction and thus conforms to strict NaNoWriMo protocol after all. But I'm not actually sure that outcome would be to the good of the book. Especially since part of it might be a script. Or two scripts. I think, if I'm honest, I have it in me to go way beyond 50,000 words this month. If I'm honest. Deep down I know I have no choice in the matter. If I ever had one, I made it a long, long time ago. The working title is Strange Bedfellows. Whether or not the pieces wind up being interrelated, it's a hell of an apt title.

Hmmph. Choosing headshots is not easy. They're fantastic shots. But all I can think is, man, I have a weird face. I mean, it's really crooked. Lopsided jowly jawline, completely uneven eyelids, weird squishy lips. You can sort of still tell I was a forceps baby. The nose is huge; there's just no getting around that. And--ugh, here's the huge difference between color and black and white--for the first time my skin is looking kind of tired. And--let's be clear--this was a really good photo shoot with an excellent photographer. I had a great time at this photo shoot. There is no doubt that that is me in the proofs. It's just really weird to realize that you're going to age into some mutant combination of Peter Lorre, Orson Welles, and Edward G. Robinson. Especially when you're a girl.

Good starting pace. I seem to be capable of 800 words an hour, and this is with occasional dilly-dallying visits to gofugyourself.com to see what Dr. Sunkentits is up to. Eight hundred words an hour...so probably all this time I've been moaning about not having enough time to write, I have been full of it. (Dangerously ambiguous pronoun there. Ahhh, yes, it is November.) More than anything else, I'm just curious about where this writing endeavor will take me. I'm tying up a lot of loose ends, in finishing these stories, but it feels as though I'm also opening myself to something totally different and big. Probably it's time to stop talking about it.

I am going to do NaNoWriMo.
I am going to get back in this summer's workout routine, even (maybe especially) if it means getting up ungodly early and buying all kinds of thermal gear for cold-weather bicycling.
I am going to submit so much writing, you'll think I'm a dang submitting machine.
I am going to have my new headshot proofs by the end of the week, and by hell I'm going to send them out. You'll think I'm...a dang submitting machine, I guess.
I am going to do all this while working full-time. I am also going to try to stop complaining about working full-time.

Considering that I have already managed the pre-NaNo desk clean-off, scotch purchase, and laundry wash, and it is still HOURS before November 1, I'm in effing great shape.

At the beginning of her ninth year of fully independent adult life, a woman should be able to a) have a working kitchen sink and b) take a shower without little bits of cilantro and coffee grounds and whatnot drifting around her ankles.

Innately comical? Yes. But it got a lot funnier when I fell off the curb just as I was saying this to N.

We're almost certainly in a Period of Broken Things here. That's fine. I've dealt with it before. I've even washed dishes in the bathtub before (see the Hollandaise Incident, January 2003: <link>http://regularb.livejournal.com/8947.html</link> and <link>http://regularb.livejournal.com/9069.html</link>). I've never before had the fruit basket plunge from the kitchen ceiling and squash several tomatoes, but hey, I guess that happens.

So last night I went grocery shopping. Butter was on sale, and I'm planning on doing some baking, so I bought two boxes. When I arrived in the kitchen, I had only one box. At this point I was already in my jammies, so I decided I was not going to retrace my steps through two blocks of alley looking for a dropped box of butter. When I got in my car this morning I discovered the butter was in fact on the floor of the passenger side, and thanks to a chilly-ish night it seemed more or less fine. So I put it in the fridge at work when I got there, and carefully removed it before I left this afternoon.

I went to see Bill Irwin give a solo performance/seminar, partly about clown, partly just about performing. Jaw-droppingly good. Brilliant. Heart-wrenching. Life-affirming. Inspiring. Bill Irwin! Oh my lord.

I went from there to yoga, buzzing with ideas.

I was at home, and in my jammies again, before I realized the butter was still in the car, which is parked in the same spot as last night, two blocks away.

So that's twice. There's some brilliant punchline coming, here. I just don't know what.

After some days with no signs of squirrel activity, other than the poor vine on the back porch, which has been getting uprooted roughly once every two days, I hazarded opening a couple of windows on Sunday. Because it was hot and I had the oven on and, really, you need to open windows then. And yes, I left the windows open and forgot about them. Today I woke up to the sounds of something moving in the next room. I came into the office to find a squirrel scrambling across my electric keyboard to dart out the hole in the window screen. Had it broken in for a quick, silent practice session? We may never know. What is more worrisome is the way, for the past half hour, the same squirrel has been coming to the window and poking its head through the screen and scolding me when it encounters the glass. I hear it doing the same thing at the clawed hole in the kitchen window (now closed again as well). Now it's worked itself entirely between the screen and the glass. Now it's back outside, standing on two legs on the electrical cable, staring at me balefully. This is not just curiosity. The squirrel is acting as though it really needs to be in here. As though it has--shudder--left something in here. The two objects I can think of are 1) food and 2) squirrel babies. The apartment is enough of a mess lately that almost any corner might have seemed an appropriate place to deposit these things. Oh, oh, oh, oh, ew.
Break out the fuzzy pants, I'm baking some plums, it's fall. La la la! I'm going to hunker down, brew some coffee, read the one novel, write 200 thousand million words, and find my wool socks.

Breaking into the pantry I can understand. But the office? Why the office? Why would you claw through the office window screen and knock over my bamboo and send the stack of research printouts cascading onto the floor? I mean, I know I don't clean all that diligently, but it can't smell that much like food in here. I'm with you, Mixer. I begin to suspect a non-squirrel species. Or--and the mauled Pop-Tarts would support this hypothesis--a squirrel novelist. He's hungry, he's wearing a tiny moth-eaten sweater vest, and he's out to sabotage my writing career. If the next thing to be attacked is the coffee--or the whiskey--we'll know. But then how do I keep him away? With deadlines? With multi-person social situations? With word that the Squirrel Pulitzer has just gone to that totally undeserving bastard who wrote the meandering second-person piece of tripe from the point of view of a female squirrel and it turned out it was all flashing through her head just as she was being run over? I have now sprinkled cayenne pepper all over the windowsills, and yes, thank you, I do feel stupid.

So. Haven't had a mouse problem for close to a year now, since I figured out how they were climbing onto the pantry shelves. Imagine, then, my surprise, on arriving home just now, to discover the Pop Tarts and chocolate chips strewn about the pantry floor, another bag shredded, a jar tipped.

Here's where it gets bad. It's not a mouse.

A large hole has been gnawed or clawed into the kitchen window screen (less than a year old: the landlord will be happy about that). I'm on the second floor.

It's an effing SQUIRREL.

If the squirrel is still in the kitchen, it's dead, because god knows those suckers can't keep quiet when they panic, and I've been clomping around and swearing enough that it would have panicked. 

Pros: Squirrels are marginally smarter than mice. This one apparently knew how to get out of the kitchen, whereas the mice always seemed to get sort of confused about that. If the pillaged shelf is any indication, bowel control is not as much of an issue for squirrels as it is for mice.

Cons: Way the hell larger. They can climb anywhere. The claws can obviously do some serious damage. I don't think you can buy an indoor squirrel trap, and I don't even want to consider how I'd handle emptying such a thing. Squirrels are cute enough to make you feel guilty for wishing them dead, too.

Sarah suggested that I sprinkle capsaicin around the window. But the cayenne doesn't seem to be doing much in the garden. (Maybe I should upgrade to pepper spray. Do you think that would work?) Sarah also mentioned a friend who has managed to keep squirrels away by pouring coyote urine around the area to be protected.

Coyote urine. Okay. It makes sense that this would work, but I have several questions. Where does one obtain coyote urine? Do you have to find the dealer standing beneath a pair of cowboy boots slung over a power line? Is there an enterpreneur out there who, even now, is scheming to become chief coyote urine supplier to the whole Midwest? Is it safe to assume my neighbors would react poorly if I started pouring coyote urine out of the second-floor window? Is it possible that, in combination with the pepper spray, it would just make our clean, woodsy little alley smell like every other alley in Chicago?

Apparently Random House has just offered Taylor Hicks $750,000 for his memoir. WHICH IS GOING TO BE GHOSTWRITTEN.

So I seem to have been going about the business all wrong. You DON'T have to put in all those years of writing and revising and filling in plot holes, and all that postage you waste on submission? Forget it! Turns out, getting published is way easier and more lucrative than I ever knew! Well, hot living damn!

Dammit, I can't even maintain a sense of humor today. Do you know what I could do with even a tenth of that amount?

How'd you get that rope burn on your ankle?

Oh, the usual way. I was hanging by my foot from the Spanish web and spinning ten feet above the floor. 

Damn straight. 

On a totally unrelated note, does anyone know anything about keeping squirrels from digging up your plants? The big-eyed little bastards have been destroying my back-porch garden, shredding the plants so badly they die. Sprinkling the plants with hair clippings and cayenne pepper (at separate times; I think using them together counts as voodoo) has had no effect.

Apparently there's such a condition as "face blindness"! Whoa! One sufferer says that when you have it two people look as similar as, say, two Irish setters.

You can get some idea of whether you have it here:
http://www.icn.ucl.ac.uk/facetests/myabilities.php

It's way the hell disconcerting to identify faces when all the hair has been cropped out of the photos. (People with the disorder often rely on hairstyle to distinguish people.) For fear of skewing friends' results, I won't say who I missed on the Famous Faces test. Let's just say it's embarrassing.

But that was a rare wrong answer, and apparently I don't have the disorder. That's good. Maybe what I have would be better termed "name deafness," or "name-face dissociative disorder," or, likelier still, "common discourtesy."

Now it's time to think about what I could write about a face-blind character. Mmm...fiction.

Anyone else having really weird dreams lately? Like where your former boss turns out to be the Devil (you can tell because his shadow has horns) and sings Prince songs while mauling you?

And yes, I know in some dreams that could be kind of hot, but in this one it was just creepy.

I barely believed there was still legal protection for free expression any more, let alone artistic expression, let alone in Utah--but check it out: Utah film sanitizers ordered to cut it Court ruling: Deleting objectionable language, sex and violence injures artistic expression By Vince Horiuchi The Salt Lake Tribune It's the kind of ending Hollywood craves. After a bitter three-year legal battle involving Utah companies that sanitize movies on DVD and VHS tape, a federal judge in Denver ruled Thursday that such editing violates U.S. copyright laws and must be stopped. In a ruling in the case involving CleanFlicks vs. 16 of Hollywood's hottest directors, U.S. District Judge Richard P. Matsch found that making copies of movies to delete objectionable language, sex and violence hurts studios and directors who own the movie rights. "Their [studios and directors] objective . . . is to stop the infringement because of its irreparable injury to the creative artistic expression in the copyrighted movies," the judge wrote in a 16-page decision. "There is a public interest in providing such protection. Their business is illegitimate." Michael Apted, director of "Coal Miner's Daughter" and president of the Director's Guild of America, said Friday that movie directors can feel "vindicated" by the ruling. "Audiences can now be assured that the films they buy or rent are the vision of the filmmakers who made them and not the arbitrary choices of a third-party editor," he said in a statement to The Salt Lake Tribune. Ray Lines, chief executive of CleanFlicks in American Fork, said he plans to meet with his attorneys Monday to discuss the ruling, but vowed to keep fighting Hollywood. "We're disappointed," he said. "This is a typical case of David vs. Goliath, but in this case, Hollywood rewrote the ending. We're going to continue to fight." CleanFlicks is a distributor that produces copies of Hollywood blockbusters on DVD by burning a scrubbed version onto a blank disc. Those versions are then sold over the Internet and to video stores around the country who offer them for rent. . . . The controversy over cleansing movies began in 1998 when the owners of Sunrise Family Video in American Fork began deleting nude scenes of Kate Winslet from the blockbuster "Titanic" for $5. And it boils down to that. Kate Winslet's boobies. I mean, they're very pretty and all, but if that's what counts as hard-core here, then maybe it really is time for me to give up and move to, I don't know, France, where you can see that kind of thing on your average beach, and experiencing pleasure--above or below the neck--is not a sin against God and country. Effing Puritans.

Now appearing in Jason's Logic 7:30, 9:15 When a plucky orphan boy saves an experimental robot from his scientist neighbor's scrap heap, it's the beginning of a friendship that could change the world. (PG)

(To be fair, when I typed in a different name it put me in Gryffindor. But it also said my Patronus was flobberworms, and sorry, no.) (Also when I put in my full first name I wound up in Slytherin.) (You can also take the "Which Harry Potter Character Would Seduce You?" test. I got Lupin. Yup: scruffy, smart, slightly animal. That's about right.)
how jedi are you? :: by lawrie malen

Just don't feel adequate to political commentary today. Thank God I'm going to be a clown. (Speaking of which: I tried silks for the first time yesterday! And got upside down! And hung there for a while! Neat!)

In the "Sorry, but it's just too easy" department: 
I just heard Paris Hilton's debut (debutante?) reggae single. It is called "Stars Are Blind."

Yeah. Deaf, too.

Mwah. Hah. Hah.

Heh.

http://www.jesuspan.com/ I never thought grilled cheese was the eucharistic meal of choice, but sure, why not? I bet it's hell to clean around the features of Our Lord, though. Christianity is the only religion that does this sort of thing, right? I mean, if I googled "Vishnu pan"...well, now, let's see... ...ah, right, 193,000 sites and a reminder that Pan is also a deity. Use quotes, B. "Vishnu skillet": nada. "Buddha pan": a blog that reads "Lay your hands on this perfect solution for countering baldness and kiss good-bye to your buddha-pan." I'm scared to click on the link. "Mohammed pan": apart from the likely attention of countless federal agents, a site excerpt that reads, verbatim, "Ash-shadu-un-laa- mohammed Pan chod-ar-rasoolullahh! Ash-shadu-un-laa- mohammed Pan chod-ar-rasoolullahh! Hayi-FUK -fallahhhhhhhh! Hayi-FUK -fallahhhhhhhh!" Seriously, I cut and pasted that. I have not changed a letter. It's on the indiaculture.net forum, if you want to check. But unless "Ash-shadu-un-laa-mohammed Pan" means "Impress the face of the one true prophet upon your flatbreads," then I have to conclude that it's just us dorky westerners who need to emblazon our holy logos upon everything we touch. Imagine what we could do if, every time we felt compelled to buy a Jesus Pan, we oh, say, maybe, gave that money to the poor. And behold, there was kitsch. And it was good. Oh, crap, and now it's 9:50. And I haven't edited a damn thing. Crap, crap. I blame the Jesus Pan.

eBayification n. Apparently the meaning has something to do with the importance of informal connections. I'm sure the muddiness of the word's meaning will not deter thousands of MBAs from seizing on it and gibbering it ad nauseum to their consulting clients. Usage: "This represents the eBayification of organizations." --Michael Schrage, a researcher at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Sloan School of Management, quoted in today's NY Times. Dude! What has English ever done to you, that you have to mistreat it like this? To quote Ken: "This word is my new pariah. I'm going to pariah-cize it. I'm placing it in total pariah-sis."

Among the headlines today: Chimp poop holds key to AIDS's origin (I know, I know. AIDS is a devastating global calamity. But when the Reuters news feed begins a headline with "Chimp poop"...oh, man.) Scientists ponder invisibility cloak Yes! Yesss! Cate Blanchette to play Bob Dylan in biopic Okay. ...Okay. Move over "Cats," a new dog musical is opening in NYC "Tails" Opens in July Clearly, it was only a matter of time, but still: why? Also, Ken Lay and Jeff Skilling are guilty. Also, chimp poop. Know what'd be great? "Chimp Poop! The Musical." But I don't know what kind of show could possibly live up to a title like that.

I'm pretty sure that the me of two years ago wouldn't have puddled up watching the "American Idol" finale. I'm okay with the puddling up--it can be inconvenient but on the whole it seems healthy--but how did I get sucked into "American Idol"? Apart from the fact that it is pure participatory drama, and proof of just how mesmerizing naked emotion and ambition can be? (Yes...yes...explain it as an acting lesson. Good.)

Woke up and edited for an hour and a half. Then went to work and edited for six hours solid. Then came home and--after a brief interlude of editing--went to the gym. Then edited for another two and a half hours (breaking, admittedly, to watch a bit of "Idol"--and they had Prince performing, Mixer, so you can't make too much fun of me). And now? More editing! Probably three more hours of it! Christ almighty. Get me to clown school. NOW.

To learn that the Chinese answer to "American Idol" is entitled "The Mongolian Cow Sour Yogurt Supergirl Contest."

Now I can sleep tonight. Thank you, Internet!

Restless as fuck. Readings tonight. Three new plays, or pieces of them. Actors with scripts in hand, lights up and lights down on a smallish stage--one of the more respected stages in Chicago--and an audience of perhaps 60 hearing lines that no audience has ever heard before. So that's theater right there, the very heart of it, the kind of thing that makes Time and the Guardian and whoever else call this city the current theater capital of the world. And I was right in the middle of it, among my people. I knew one of the playwrights--I mean, because it was Terry--as well as the artistic director of the respected smallish stage (though, admittedly, I gave him a really crap audition last month and he kind of looked through me tonight); I heard the new plays and listened and laughed and thought about what they implied for what I'm writing and how I will perform the next time I'm onstage (if I can stop having crappy auditions long enough to ever get another role) and what I think about the medium in general. So why the bloody hell doesn't it feel like enough? I don't mean I have a little touch of Martha Graham's divine unrest. I mean this is not remotely close to enough. I mean every stage in this city, respected and otherwise, feels too goddamn small. Oh, crap, crap, crap. Show me a wall and I'll claw at it. Italy is not going to come soon enough. I'll go mad first. Where the hell can I go? How can I pay for it? Hmm.
There are so many jokes waiting to be made here, and I just don't have the time to do it: http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20060516/ap_on_sc/elephant_treadmill_1 Nb: Elephant. Treadmill. Treadmill!

The contract is signed, the deal is done...Press 53 is going to publish my book of short stories next year. WOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOHOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO!!! Also, now I have a bike. It needs a name. A boy name.

Apparently James Baldwin said of Ralph Ellison: "Ellison is as angry as anybody can be and still live."

I love this line.

I am not (alas) Ralph Ellison, nor have I spent my entire life being subjected to systematic racism and violence, but this is the kind of anger I am feeling these days. I am roaring and boiling to do something. 

I don't know what's going to come out of this--a political play, another smashed glass, a final falling-out with a person or two, a rebound fling, a road trip, an indie rock career, an opera, a drunken punch, the bomb story, a religious experience, some sort of militant advocacy, maybe all of the above--but it's going to be very interesting.

Huge blister on my middle finger, which I think means that the new song ("Rose of Jericho") is pretty dang good. If so, hooray. Either way, typing is a whole lot harder and more painful.

If there's anything more guaranteed to make you feel totally useless and inept than filling out your income tax returns, I don't know what it is. Especially if, say, you haven't done the best record keeping this year, and have to figure out a few deductions by going page by page through last year's planner, where you are confronted in capital letters--and sometimes highlighter--by your GLARING FAILURES to do EVEN HALF THE THINGS YOU PLANNED and by a number of BALLS YOU DROPPED, from the relatively common FRIENDS WHOSE SHOWS YOU MISSED to the heartburn-inducing CLIENT HOURS YOU POSSIBLY FORGOT TO INVOICE. Oof. 

And this is before calculating the self-employment tax, which doesn't care whether you were barely scraping by; in fact, it thinks you could go ahead and scrape by on 35% less.

Friends, strangers, learn from my mistake: do not be self-employed at any job about which you are less than 100% passionate. It is just nowhere near worth it.

Do other people flounder around this much, or is it just me?

Just had to do an image search on the word "Kreon" (I'm annotating an edition of Antigone and god, I love my job). Anyway, it yielded one of the strangest collections of images I've seen in a while. Kreon is apparently the name of a German manufacturer (of industrial components and pills?) and for some reason the word also calls up a bunch of images of Soviet-era robotics, as well as some abstract modern art (I'm guessing "Kreon" is "crayon" somewhere in Eastern Europe). Add to that two fine-blooded racehorses, some ancient masks, and the expected smattering of young-looking actors in low-rent productions (including one smirking guy in a 1950s suit and what looks like a Burger King crown), and you have a nice healthy dose of modern absurdity, or else fodder for a suspense potboiler. Hmmm...The Kreon Konspiracy. How fast do you think I'd get sued?

This just in, from today's KEXP playlist: 'Playing The Clash made me a terror suspect' by ANNE CAMPBELL, Metro 08:06am 5th April 2006 A mobile phone salesman was hauled off a plane and questioned for three hours as a terror suspect - because he listened to songs by The Clash and Led Zeppelin. Harraj Mann, 24, played the punk anthem London Calling and classic rock track Immigrant Song in a taxi before a flight to London. The lyrics to both tracks made the driver fear his passenger was a terrorist. THE WORDS OF THE CLASH TRACK BEGIN: "LONDON CALLING TO THE FARAWAY TOWNS, NOW WAR IS DECLARED AND BATTLE COME DOWN." AND LED ZEP'S IMMIGRANT SONG GOES: "THE HAMMER OF THE GODS WILL DRIVE OUR SHIPS TO NEW LANDS, TO FIGHT THE HORDE, SINGING AND CRYING: VALHALLA, I AM COMING!" [capital letters theirs] Mr Mann, of Hartlepool, Teesside, had boarded the plane at Durham Tees Valley Airport when the flight to Heathrow was stopped and he was arrested by police. He said he was told he was being questioned under the Terrorism Act and his choice of music had aroused suspicions. Mr Mann said yesterday: 'The taxi had one of those tape deck things that plugs into your digital music player. "I played Procol Harum's Whiter Shade Of Pale first, which the taxi man liked. I figured he liked the classics so put on a bit of Led Zeppelin - Immigrant Song - which he didn't like. Then, since I was going to London, I played the song by The Clash and finished up with Nowhere Man by The Beatles." Mr Mann said he was 'frog-marched off the plane in front of everyone, had my bags searched and was asked 'every question you can think of'. He added: "It turned out the taxi driver alerted someone when I arrived at the airport and had spoken about my music. He didn't like Led Zep or The Clash but there was no need to tell the police." Durham Police said the action was taken 'as a result of information received' and the flight was stopped before take-off. ### Holy CRAP. I guess I'm not moving to London, then. I'd love to think this was a joke but unfortunately it probably isn't one. What ridiculous hoops we are all jumping through lately. In fact, there's actually a story I really want to write about a pair of schmos who try to blow up the Empire State building, but I'm kind of nervous about doing the necessary research. And that is just goddamn stupid. I'm a FICTION WRITER. In the UNITED STATES. I am supposed to be able to write whatever the hell I want. Grr. At the risk of being hauled in for questioning, I'm going to make the only other appropriate comment I can think of, which is--naturally--a Joe Strummer lyric: You have the right to freeee speech As long as you're not dumb enough To actually try it.

Two hours of script rewrites and I think I may not be helping the story at all. Dammit. Dammit. Dammit. Why can't I make it work? Is it less broken than I think? Or just completely and utterly unfixable?

Stupid second act. Stupid deadline.

From today's NY Times:
Mr. Hare said that he felt American audiences would respond to the play, even if, he said, it was unlikely that a work like "Stuff Happens" could ever transfer to Broadway because of its large cast (16 actors). "It's not politics, it's economics," he said, though he added that he felt American theater makers had not really stepped up to the challenge of the war. 

"Certainly from Los Angeles my impression is that the American audience is way ahead of the American theater establishment," Mr. Hare said, speaking of the 2005 production. "For some reason in America the theater has also been largely collusive in offering escapist entertainment, as if we were living through the Depression or as if we were living through a war that we all agree on. Actually, we're fighting a war that we don't agree on. And I wish I saw more signs in the American theater of that dissent being dramatized."


Go forth, my children, and make shows.

I'm tired of the old shit.
Let the new shit begin.

--Eels
Okay, God, or whatever You are, just help me get through the rest of this You-forsaken week, and I'll try not to ask for anything else for a while. We cool?

From Yahoo's Broadway news: "We're getting fewer and fewer original, surprising journeys in the theater," [Producer Kevin] McCollum said. "This season this [The Drowsy Chaperone] is the only thing that has no source material." Well. That sounds to me like a challenge.

Okay then. For the first time in nearly two years, I don't know what I'm doing next. I still seem to be a writer. I've been writing prose again this week, revisiting Bird by Bird, feeling a couple of plots (both old and new) nudge me, even sending out a collection of stories. Got a really nice rejection slip on a batch of poems last week, too, the kind of thing that makes you think, hey, maybe there is an audience for these things. I think I might be done sending Rook out, though. Which is sad. It feels like a waste of a hell of a lot of work. But I'm not sure I care about it passionately enough to sell it any more. Some might, of course, say that's the perfect mental state to be in before you send your work out. But oh hell, it's tough. I'm pretty damn sure I'm still an actor, too, if this crankiness and restlessness about auditions is any indication. God, I must be missing acting if the MFA is starting to seem appealing again. So I need to get the hell back on stage. Definitely still a coffee drinker. Being a playwright was never really the plan, until I got an idea and knew it had to be a play. Being a musician wasn't really the plan either, but--well, I am one. I'm still really interested in history, and classical languages, though I wonder if it's necessary to get a degree in them to do what I want to do. I'm 30. February always makes me think about leaving this city, but I'm wondering increasingly if I can have the acting career I want here. There's New York, of course, but...hmm. Well. I can legally work in London. I don't know if I can have the acting career I want there, either, actually, but I like the British approach to acting a whole lot. Deep down there's also, still, a very quiet and neglected shaggy-haired girl who loves to draw, and in drawing can achieve the kind of pure and complete inner peace one rarely finds elsewhere. Well: and what the hell do I do with all this? and what the hell kind of arrogance is it to expect that my life will actually conform with whatever plan I make for it?

From today's NY Times, on the Muhammed-satirizing cartoons: 

Last week a State Department spokesman, Sean McCormack, simultaneously condemned the cartoons as "unacceptable" and spoke up for free speech, while the Joint Chiefs of Staff were firing off a letter to The Washington Post about a cartoon it ran in which Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, in the guise of a doctor, says to a heavily bandaged soldier who has lost his arms and legs, "I'm listing your condition as 'battle hardened.' " The letter called the cartoon, by Tom Toles, "reprehensible" and offensive to soldiers.

The Post's editorial page editor, Fred Hiatt, replied that the newspaper would not censor its cartoonists, inspiring John Aravosis, who runs Americablog (americablog.blogspot.com), the Web site where the letter was first reported, to tell Editor & Publisher magazine: "Now that the Joint Chiefs have addressed the insidious threat cartoons pose to our troops, perhaps they can move on to the less pressing issues like getting them their damn body armor."

HA! Yes, we can hope so. Please, remind me of this week the next time I'm complaining that no one notices art in today's world.
